did.abstract: Deborah Gerson is a sociology professor at San Francisco State University. She studied at the University of California, Berkeley, and earned her Ph.D. in sociology from San Francisco State University with her dissertation, "Practice from Pain: Building a Women's Movement through Consciousness Raising." She has also taught courses in Womens Studies at the City College of San Francisco. She is the daughter of Communist Party of the United States (CPUSA) activists Simon and Sophie Gerson, and participated in political, cultural, educational activities led or supported by the Party during her childhood. This collection consists of eight sound recordings on audio cassette. The recordings consists of oral history interviews by Deborah Gerson with family members Sophie Gerson and Bill Gerson, as well as other activists affiliated with the CPUSA: elder rights activist Rose Kryzack, CPUSA Families Committee organizer Monette Solataroff Weinstone, organizer and author Peggy Dennis, and civil rights activist Esther Cooper Jackson. Topics and themes addressed in the interviews include teenage political activities, the Smith Act trials of Communist Party leaders, surveillance of CPUSA members, and the impact of surveillance of activist social movements on individuals and families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of eight sound recordings on audio cassette. The recordings consists of oral history interviews by Deborah Gerson with her mother Sophie Gerson and brother Bill Gerson, as well as other activists affiliated with the Communist Party, USA: elder rights activist Rose Kryzack, CPUSA Families Committee organizer Monette Solataroff Weinstone, organizer and author Peggy Dennis, and civil rights activist Esther Cooper Jackson. Topics and themes addressed in the interviews include teenage political activities, the Smith Act trials of Communist Party leaders, surveillance of CPUSA members, and the impact of surveillance of activist social movements on individuals and families.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
